cleaned_text: COVID-19 pandemic |COVID-19 pandemic| | | |Disease|[Severe acute 2019 [Public health emergency of international concern](/wiki/Public_health_emergency_of_international_concern): 30 January 2020 - 5 May 2023 (3 years, 3 months and 5 days) [[3]](#cite_note-Template:COVID-19_data-3) pandemic, also known as the coronavirus pandemic, is a global [pandemic](/wiki/Pandemic) of [coronavirus disease 2019](/wiki/Coronavirus_disease_2019) (COVID-19) caused by syndrome coronavirus 2](/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2) (SARS-CoV-2). The [novel virus](/wiki/Novel_virus) was first identified in an outbreak in the Chinese city of [Wuhan](/wiki/Wuhan) in December 2019. Attempts to contain it there failed, allowing the virus to spread to other areas of Asia and later [worldwide](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_by_country_and_territory) in 2020. The [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) (WHO) declared the outbreak a [public health emergency of international concern](/wiki/Public_health_emergency_of_international_concern) (PHEIC) on 30 January 2020. The WHO ended its PHEIC declaration on 5 May 2023. As of 7 September 2023, the pandemic had caused 770,436,563 [[3]](#cite_note-Template:COVID-19_data-3) cases and 6,956,887 [[3]](#cite_note-Template:COVID-19_data-3) confirmed deaths, ranking it the [deadliest and pandemics in history](/wiki/Deadliest_pandemics_in_history). [COVID-19 symptoms](/wiki/COVID-19_symptoms) range from to deadly, but most commonly include fever, [nocturnal cough](/wiki/Nocturnal_cough), and fatigue. [Transmission of the virus](/wiki/Transmission_of_COVID-19) is airborne particles](/wiki/Airborne_transmission). Mutations have [produced many vaccines](/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine) were [widely December 2020. [Treatments](/wiki/Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19) include [novel antiviral drugs](/wiki/COVID-19_drug_development) and symptom control. Common mitigation measures during the public health emergency included [travel restrictions](/wiki/Travel_restrictions_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic), [lockdowns](/wiki/COVID-19_lockdowns), business [testing](/wiki/COVID-19_testing) systems, and The pandemic caused severe [social](/wiki/Social_impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic) and [economic disruption](/wiki/Economic_impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic) around the world, including chain disruptions](/wiki/2021%E2%80%932022_global_supply_chain_crisis) and [panic buying](/wiki/Panic_buying). Reduced human activity led to an [unprecedented decrease in pollution](/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_the_environment). [Educational institutions](/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_education) and public areas were partially or fully closed in many jurisdictions, and events were cancelled or postponed during 2020 and 2021. Terminology In [epidemiology](/wiki/Epidemiology), a pandemic is defined as "an epidemic occurring over a very wide area, crossing international boundaries, and usually affecting a large number of people". During the COVID-19 pandemic, as with other pandemics, the meaning of this term has been challenged. The initial practice of naming them according to where the variants were identified (e.g. [Delta](/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Delta_variant) began as the "Indian variant") is no longer common. Many early cases were linked to people who had visited the [Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market](/wiki/Huanan_Seafood_Wholesale_Market) there, [[26]](#cite_note-Sun2020epidemiology-26) [[27]](#cite_note-27) [[28]](#cite_note-Maxmen2021whoReport-28) but it is possible that human-to-human transmission began earlier. [[29]](#cite_note-Hu2020natureReviews-29) [[30]](#cite_note-Graham2020immunity-30) The scientific consensus is that the virus is most likely of a [zoonotic](/wiki/Zoonotic) origin, from bats or another closely related mammal. [[29]](#cite_note-Hu2020natureReviews-29) [[31]](#cite_note-31) [[32]](#cite_note-To2021lessons-32) Controversies about the origins of the virus, including the [lab leak theory](/wiki/COVID-19_lab_leak_theory), heightened geopolitical divisions, notably between the United States and China. [[40]](#cite_note-40) [[41]](#cite_note-41) Cases Official "case" counts refer to the number of people who have been [tested for COVID-19](/wiki/COVID-19_testing) and whose test has been confirmed positive according to official protocols whether or not they experienced symptomatic disease. [[42]](#cite_note-1ceLG-42) [[43]](#cite_note-J0rix-43) Due to the effect of [sampling bias](/wiki/Sampling_bias), studies which obtain a more accurate number by extrapolating from a random sample have consistently found that total infections considerably exceed the reported case counts. [[44]](#cite_note-WqXOo-44) [[45]](#cite_note-BtFLV-45) Many countries, early on, had official policies to not test those with only mild symptoms. [[46]](#cite_note-elpais640000-46) [[47]](#cite_note-20200313reuters-47) The strongest risk factors for severe illness are obesity, [complications of diabetes](/wiki/Complications_of_diabetes), anxiety disorders, and the total number of conditions. [[48]](#cite_note-48) During the start of the COVID-19 pandemic it was not clear whether young people were less likely to be infected, or less likely to develop symptoms and be tested. [[49]](#cite_note-vox21190033-49) A retrospective [cohort study](/wiki/Cohort_study) in China found that [children](/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_children) and adults were just as likely to be infected. [[50]](#cite_note-489Q3-50) Among more thorough studies, [preliminary results](/wiki/COVID-19_Case-Cluster-Study) from 9 April 2020, found that in [Gangelt](/wiki/Gangelt), the centre of a major infection cluster in Germany, 15 percent of a population sample tested positive for [antibodies](/wiki/Antibody). [[51]](#cite_note-otW1O-51) Screening for COVID-19 in pregnant women [in New York City](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_New_York_City), and [blood donors](/wiki/Blood_donor) in the Netherlands, found rates of positive antibody tests that indicated more infections than reported. [[52]](#cite_note-rCdvL-52) [[53]](#cite_note-20200416reuters-53) [Seroprevalence](/wiki/Seroprevalence)-based estimates are conservative as some studies show that persons with mild symptoms do not have detectable antibodies. [[54]](#cite_note-0LgFK-54) Initial estimates of the [basic reproduction number](/wiki/Basic_reproduction_number) (R0) for COVID-19 in January 2020 were between 1.4 and 2.5, [[55]](#cite_note-WFNfK-55) but a subsequent analysis claimed that it may be about 5.7 (with a 95 percent [confidence interval](/wiki/Confidence_interval) of 3.8 to 8.9). [[59]](#cite_note-57percent1-59) [[60]](#cite_note-57percent2-60) Deaths As of 10 March 2023, more than 6.88 million [[5]](#cite_note-JHU_ticker-5) deaths had been attributed to COVID-19. The first confirmed death was in Wuhan on 9 January 2020. [[62]](#cite_note-AutoDW-25-62) These numbers vary by region and over time, influenced by testing volume, healthcare system quality, treatment options, government response, [[63]](#cite_note-63) time since the initial outbreak, and population characteristics, such as age, sex, and overall health. [[64]](#cite_note-worldindata-64) Multiple measures are used to quantify mortality. [[65]](#cite_note-wBm2a-65) Official death counts typically include people who died after testing positive. Such counts exclude deaths without a test. [[66]](#cite_note-20200331reuters-66) Conversely, deaths of people who died from underlying conditions following a positive test may be included. [[67]](#cite_note-stuff120443722-67) Countries such as Belgium include deaths from suspected cases, including those without a test, thereby increasing counts. [[68]](#cite_note-npr841005901-68) Official death counts have been claimed to underreport the actual death toll, because [excess mortality](/wiki/Mortality_displacement) (the number of deaths in a period compared to a long-term average) data show an increase in deaths that is not explained by COVID-19 deaths alone. [[69]](#cite_note-:7-69) Using such data, estimates of the true number of deaths from COVID-19 worldwide have included a range from 16.5 to 26.8 million (20.2 million) by 3 February 2023 by [The Economist](/wiki/The_Economist), [[70]](#cite_note-70) [[69]](#cite_note-:7-69) as well as over 18.5 million by 1 April 2023 by the [Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation](/wiki/Institute_for_Health_Metrics_and_Evaluation) [[71]](#cite_note-COVID-19_Projections-71) and 18.2 million (earlier) deaths between 1 January 2020, and 31 December 2021, by a comprehensive international study. [[72]](#cite_note-10.1016/S0140-6736(21)02796-3-72) Such deaths include deaths due to healthcare capacity constraints and priorities, as well as reluctance to seek care (to avoid possible infection). [[73]](#cite_note-20200429reason-73) Further research may help distinguish the proportions directly caused by COVID-19 from those caused by indirect consequences of the pandemic. [[72]](#cite_note-10.1016/S0140-6736(21)02796-3-72) In May 2022, the WHO estimated the number of excess deaths by the end of 2021 to be 14.9 million compared to 5.4 million reported COVID-19 deaths, with the majority of the unreported 9.5 million deaths believed to be direct deaths due the virus, rather than indirect deaths. Some deaths were because [people with other conditions could not access medical services](/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_other_health_issues). [[74]](#cite_note-74) [[75]](#cite_note-75) A December 2022 [WHO](/wiki/WHO) study estimated excess deaths from the pandemic during 2020 and 2021, again concluding 14.8 million excess early deaths occurred, reaffirming and detailing their prior calculations from May as well as updating them, addressing criticisms. These numbers do not include measures like [years of potential life lost](/wiki/Years_of_potential_life_lost) and may make the pandemic 2021's [leading cause of death](/wiki/List_of_causes_of_death_by_rate). [[88]](#cite_note-88) IFRs rise as a function of age (from 0.002% at age 10 and 0.01% at age 25, to 0.4% at age 55, 1.4% at age 65, 4.6% at age 75, and 15% at age 85). These rates vary by a factor of 10,000 across the age groups. [[81]](#cite_note-EJE_levinetal-81) For comparison, the IFR for middle-aged adults is two orders of magnitude higher than the annualised risk of a fatal automobile accident and much higher than the risk of dying from [seasonal influenza](/wiki/Seasonal_influenza). [[81]](#cite_note-EJE_levinetal-81) In December 2020, a systematic review and meta-analysis estimated that population-weighted IFR was 0.5% to 1% in some countries (France, Netherlands, New Zealand, and Portugal), 1% to 2% in other countries (Australia, England, Lithuania, and Spain), and about 2.5% in Italy. This study reported that most of the differences reflected corresponding differences in the population's age structure and the age-specific pattern of infections. [[81]](#cite_note-EJE_levinetal-81) There have also been reviews that have compared the fatality rate of this pandemic with prior pandemics, such as MERS-CoV. [[90]](#cite_note-90) Case fatality ratio (CFR) Another metric in assessing death rate is the [case fatality ratio](/wiki/Case_fatality_rate) (CFR), [[a]](#cite_note-91) which is the ratio of deaths to diagnoses. This metric can be misleading because of the delay between symptom onset and death and because testing focuses on symptomatic individuals. [[91]](#cite_note-Hauser_2020-92) Based on [Johns Hopkins University](/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_University) statistics, the global CFR is 1.02 percent (6,881,955 deaths for 676,609,955 cases) as of 10 March 2023. [[5]](#cite_note-JHU_ticker-5) The number varies by region and has generally declined over time. [[92]](#cite_note-b0L7I-93) Disease Variants Several variants have been named by WHO and labelled as a [variant of concern](/wiki/Variant_of_concern) (VoC) or a [variant of interest](/wiki/Variant_of_interest) (VoI). Many of these variants have shared the more infectious [D614G](/wiki/D614G). As of May 2023, the WHO had downgraded all variants of concern to previously circulating as these were no longer detected in new infections. [[93]](#cite_note-94) [[94]](#cite_note-CDC2-95) Sub-lineages of the Omicron variant (BA.1 - BA.5) were considered separate VoCs by the WHO until they were downgraded in March 2023 as no longer widely circulating. symptoms Symptoms of COVID-19 are variable, ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness. [[97]](#cite_note-CDC2020Sym-98) [[98]](#cite_note-Grant_et_al_2020-99) Common symptoms include headache, [[97]](#cite_note-CDC2020Sym-98) People with the same infection may have different symptoms, and their symptoms may change over time. Three common clusters of symptoms have been identified: one respiratory symptom cluster with cough, [sputum](/wiki/Sputum), shortness of breath, and fever; a musculoskeletal symptom cluster with muscle and joint pain, headache, and fatigue; a cluster of digestive symptoms with abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhoea. [[99]](#cite_note-ECDC-100) In people without prior ear, nose, and throat disorders, [loss of taste](/wiki/Hypogeusia) combined with [loss of smell](/wiki/Hyposmia) is associated with [COVID-19](/wiki/COVID-19) and is reported in as many as 88% of cases. [[100]](#cite_note-Krishnan-101) [[101]](#cite_note-102) [[102]](#cite_note-pmid32483687-103) Transmission The disease is mainly transmitted via the respiratory route when people inhale droplets and small airborne particles (that form an [aerosol](/wiki/Aerosol)) that infected people exhale as they breathe, talk, cough, sneeze, or sing. [[103]](#cite_note-Wang_2021-104) [[104]](#cite_note-auto-105) [[105]](#cite_note-AR2021-106) [[106]](#cite_note-auto1-107) Infected people are more likely to transmit COVID-19 when they are physically close to other non-infected individuals. However, infection can occur over longer distances, particularly indoors. [[103]](#cite_note-Wang_2021-104) [[107]](#cite_note-Miller_2021-108) Cause SARSCoV2 belongs to the broad family of viruses known as [coronaviruses](/wiki/Coronavirus). [[108]](#cite_note-Fox2020-109) It is a [positive-sense single-stranded RNA](/wiki/Positive-sense_single-stranded_RNA_virus) (+ssRNA) virus, with a single linear RNA segment. Coronaviruses infect humans, other mammals, including livestock and companion animals, and avian species. [[109]](#cite_note-V'kovskik:21-110) Human coronaviruses are capable of causing illnesses ranging from the [common cold](/wiki/Common_cold) to more severe diseases such as [Middle East respiratory syndrome](/wiki/Middle_East_respiratory_syndrome) (MERS, fatality rate 34%). SARS-CoV-2 is the seventh known to infect people, [NL63](/wiki/Human_coronavirus_NL63), [OC43](/wiki/Human_coronavirus_OC43), [HKU1](/wiki/Human_coronavirus_HKU1), [MERS-CoV](/wiki/Middle_East_respiratory_syndrome-related_coronavirus), and the original [SARS-CoV](/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus). [[110]](#cite_note-NEJM-Novel-111) Diagnosis The standard method of testing for presence of SARS-CoV-2 is a [nucleic acid test](/wiki/Nucleic_acid_test), [[111]](#cite_note-20200130cdc-112) which detects the presence of viral RNA fragments. [[112]](#cite_note-WHO_InterimGuidance-113) As these tests detect RNA but not infectious virus, its "ability to determine duration of infectivity of patients is limited." [[113]](#cite_note-2k0iS-114) The test is typically done on respiratory samples obtained by a [nasopharyngeal swab](/wiki/Nasopharyngeal_swab); however, a nasal swab or sputum sample may also be used. [[114]](#cite_note-CDC2020Testing-115) [[115]](#cite_note-20200129cdc-116) The WHO has published several testing protocols for the disease. [[116]](#cite_note-117) Prevention Preventive measures to reduce the chances of infection include getting vaccinated, staying at home or spending more time outdoors, avoiding crowded places, keeping distance from others, wearing a mask in public, ventilating indoor spaces, managing potential exposure durations, washing hands with soap and water often and for at least twenty seconds, practicing good respiratory hygiene, and avoiding touching the eyes, nose, or mouth with unwashed hands. [[117]](#cite_note-cdc-prev-118) [[118]](#cite_note-who2023-119) Those diagnosed with COVID-19 or who believe they may be infected are advised by healthcare authorities to stay home except to get medical care, call ahead before visiting a healthcare provider, wear a face mask before entering the healthcare provider's office and when in any room or vehicle with another person, cover coughs and sneezes with a tissue, regularly wash hands with soap and water and avoid sharing personal household items. [[119]](#cite_note-120) [[120]](#cite_note-121) [[121]](#cite_note-122) Vaccines A COVID-19 [vaccine](/wiki/Vaccine) is intended to immunity](/wiki/Acquired_immunity) against [severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2](/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2) virus that causes coronavirus disease 2019 ( [COVID-19](/wiki/COVID-19)). Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, an established body of knowledge existed about the structure and function of [coronaviruses](/wiki/Coronavirus) causing diseases like [severe acute respiratory syndrome](/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome) (SARS) and [Middle East respiratory syndrome](/wiki/Middle_East_respiratory_syndrome) (MERS). This knowledge accelerated the development of various [vaccine platforms](/wiki/Vaccine_platform) during early 2020. [[122]](#cite_note-pmid33341119-123) The initial focus of SARS-CoV-2 vaccines was on preventing symptomatic and severe illness. [[123]](#cite_note-124) The COVID-19 vaccines are widely credited for their role in reducing the severity and death caused by COVID-19. [[124]](#cite_note-125) [[125]](#cite_note-126) As of March 2023, more than 5.5 billion people had received one or more doses [[126]](#cite_note-127) (11.8 billion in total) in over 197 countries. The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine was the most widely used. [[127]](#cite_note-128) According to a June 2022 study, COVID-19 vaccines prevented an additional 14.4 million to 19.8 million deaths in 185 countries and territories from 8 December 2020 to 8 December 2021. [[128]](#cite_note-129) [[129]](#cite_note-130) On 8 November 2022, the first recombinant protein-based COVID-19 vaccine (Novavax's booster [Nuvaxovid](/wiki/Nuvaxovid)) was authorized for use in adults in the United Kingdom. It has subsequently received endorsement/authorization from the WHO, US, European Union, and Australia. [[130]](#cite_note-131) [[131]](#cite_note-132) On 12 November 2022, the WHO released its Global Vaccine Market Report. The report indicated that "inequitable distribution is not unique to COVID-19 vaccines"; countries that are not economically strong struggle to obtain vaccines. [[132]](#cite_note-133) On 14 November 2022, the first inhalable vaccine was introduced, developed by Chinese biopharmaceutical company [CanSino Biologics](/wiki/CanSino_Biologics#COVID-19_vaccine_development), in the city of Shanghai, China. [[133]](#cite_note-134) Treatment For the first two years of the pandemic, no specific and effective treatment or cure was available. [[134]](#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-135) [[135]](#cite_note-cdcmuseum-136) In 2021, the European Medicines Agency's (EMA) Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use (CHMP) approved the oral antiviral [protease inhibitor](/wiki/Protease_inhibitor_(pharmacology)), [Paxlovid](/wiki/Paxlovid) (nirmatrelvir plus AIDS drug [ritonavir](/wiki/Ritonavir)), to treat adult patients. [[136]](#cite_note-137) FDA later gave it an EUA. [[137]](#cite_note-138) Most cases of COVID-19 are mild. In these, supportive care includes medication such as [paracetamol](/wiki/Paracetamol) or [NSAIDs](/wiki/NSAID) to relieve symptoms (fever, [[138]](#cite_note-139) body aches, cough), adequate intake of oral fluids and rest. [[135]](#cite_note-cdcmuseum-136) [[139]](#cite_note-140) Good personal hygiene and a [healthy diet](/wiki/Healthy_diet) are also recommended. [[140]](#cite_note-141) [Supportive care](/wiki/Supportive_care) [oxygen support](/wiki/Oxygen_support) and [prone positioning](/wiki/Prone_positioning), and or devices to support other affected vital organs. [[141]](#cite_note-142) More severe cases may need treatment in hospital. In those with low oxygen levels, use of the [glucocorticoid](/wiki/Glucocorticoid) [dexamethasone](/wiki/Dexamethasone) is recommended to reduce mortality. [[142]](#cite_note-143) [Noninvasive ventilation](/wiki/Noninvasive_ventilation) and, ultimately, admission to an [intensive care unit](/wiki/Intensive_care_unit) for [mechanical ventilation](/wiki/Mechanical_ventilation) may be required to support breathing. [[143]](#cite_note-NIHGuidelines2020-144) [Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation](/wiki/Extracorporeal_membrane_oxygenation) (ECMO) has been used to address the issue of respiratory failure. [[144]](#cite_note-Guan_Ni_Hu_Liang_p.-145) [[145]](#cite_note-Henry_2020_p.-146) Existing drugs such as [hydroxychloroquine](/wiki/Hydroxychloroquine), [lopinavir/ritonavir](/wiki/Lopinavir/ritonavir), and [ivermectin](/wiki/Ivermectin) are not recommended by US or European health authorities, as there is no good evidence they have any useful effect. [[134]](#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-135) [[146]](#cite_note-Kim_Read_Fauci_p=2149-147) [[147]](#cite_note-NIHGuidelinesTherapeuticManagement-148) The antiviral [remdesivir](/wiki/Remdesivir) is available in the US, Canada, Australia, and several other countries, with varying restrictions; however, it is not recommended for use with mechanical ventilation, and is discouraged altogether by the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) (WHO), [[148]](#cite_note-Hsu_p=m4457-149) due to limited evidence of its efficacy. [[134]](#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-135) Prognosis The severity of COVID-19 varies. It may take a mild course with few or no symptoms, resembling other common upper respiratory diseases such as the [common cold](/wiki/Common_cold). In 3-4% of cases (7.4% for those over age 65) symptoms are severe enough to cause hospitalization. [[149]](#cite_note-pmid33087398-150) Mild cases typically recover within two weeks, while those with severe or critical diseases may take three to six weeks to recover. Among those who have died, the time from symptom onset to death has ranged from two to eight weeks. Prolonged [prothrombin](/wiki/Prothrombin) time and elevated [C-reactive protein](/wiki/C-reactive_protein) levels on admission to the hospital are associated with severe course of COVID-19 and with a transfer to [intensive care units](/wiki/Intensive_care_unit) (ICU).
